title: Desktop File Learning
content:
How to add a shortcuts on Linux?

We often download the software from the software’s official website . But sometimes the software is a zip which include the binary file of the software. For example, I download a Firefox browser form its official website, but I can’t get a .deb file. So I don’t need it and can’t install it, so how can I add a shortcuts to launcher.

Desktop Entry file is used to describe the startup configuration information of the program in the Linux desktop system.

so many Linux release support the launcher which is used to manage the program centrally. The launcher on my machine is located in the /usr/share/applications directory. We can see so many .desktop file in there. Every .desktop file in there is a program entry and you can set a logo of shortcuts. That’s so friendly.

Desktop file example

[Desktop Entry]
Name=<application name>
Type=Application
Exec=<appliction full path>
Icon=<appliction logo full path>

It’s a easy example.

  1. Name: It’s the name which the file display finally
  2. Type: it’s used to set the type of the desktop file
  3. Exec: it’s full path of the binary exec file
  4. Icon: it’s full path of the logo, the best size is 128x128

Of course, You can add a element called Categories. it’s useful if you want to classify.

Now let’s have a try.

[Desktop Entry]
Name=Firefox
Type=Application
Exec=/home/a1andns/Software/firefox/firefox
Icon=/home/a1andns/Software/firefox/browser/chrome/icons/default/default128.png
Categories=Network

I get a great shortcut. Now I will move it to the launcher.

a1andns@a1andns-PC:~/Software/firefox$ sudo mv firefox.desktop /usr/share/applications

Nice !!!

We can see it in launcher’s network category.

This is my first English Blog, that’s look just so so .
